title: Newton 2L rotation - disk friction - disk inertia

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students has a horizontal disk that can rotate on a fixed vertical axle at its center, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>1</mtext></math>. A string of negligible mass is wrapped around a groove at the disk’s edge, as indicated, and the diameter of the groove is measured to be <math alttext="D sub G equals 15 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>D</mi><mtext>G</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></math>.

The students notice that there is friction between the disk and the axle, and wish to experimentally determine the magnitude <math alttext="tau sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> of the frictional torque exerted on the disk when it spins. The frictional torque can be assumed to be constant. The students are NOT able to remove the disk from the axle and the mounting platform, or directly determine the mass or the rotational inertia of the disk. They have access to a force probe, several rulers, a meterstick, and several stopwatches.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to experimentally determine <math alttext="tau sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> by making a linear graph. In your description, include the measurements to be made along with the corresponding equipment needed for each measurement. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

Later the students are at a playground, where there is a large rotatable disk as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The disk has metal bars that people can hold on to while the disk spins about a vertical axle at its center. The students wish to experimentally determine the rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub d b" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>db</mtext></msub></math> of the disk-bars system.

Using a force sensor and some rope attached to one of the metal bars, one of the students pulls tangentially to cause the disk to starting spinning from rest, as shown in the top view of Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The students record the average force <math alttext="F sub average" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>avg</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> recorded by the force sensor and the amount of time <math alttext="t sub F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>F</mi></msub></mstyle></math> that the force was applied. After the force is removed, they record the time <math alttext="t sub 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>8</mn></msub></mstyle></math> that it takes the disk to rotate <math alttext="8" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn></math> full revolutions. They measure the perpendicular distance <math alttext="R sub F equals 2.00 meters" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>F</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> from the extension of the rope to the center of the disk, and are also able to determine that the disk rotates with negligible friction about its axle. Five experimental trials are conducted, and the results of the experiment are shown in the table.

The students correctly determine that the relationship between <math alttext="t sub F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>F</mi></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="t sub 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>8</mn></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F sub average" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>avg</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is given by:

\(\frac{1}{t_st_8}=\frac{R_{\text{F}}}{16\pi I_{\text{db}}}F_{\text{avg}}\)
